content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Accessibility Tree with numerical label representing information about the page, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
4) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {Accessibility Tree of a web page}

Now given a task: Find and book a hotel in Paris with suitable accommodations for a family of four (two adults and two children) offering free cancellation for the dates of February 14-21, 2024.  Please interact with https://www.booking.com/ and get the answer.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to set destination to Paris in search box. Combobox [54] is "Where are you going?".  
Action: Type [54]; Paris
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to locate “Previous month” arrow to reach Feb 2024, but calendar only shows “Next month”. Clicking “Next month” once should make both arrows appear, letting us then navigate backward.  
Action: Click [7046]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Calendar now shows May 2025; need February 2024, so go backward.  
Action: Click [15449]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to move calendar back toward Feb 2024; the “Previous month” arrow button (id 15449) should move one month earlier.  
Action: Click [15449]

Action: Click [7005]

Thought: The calendar is currently closed; to pick the February 14–21 2024 dates we must reopen it. The “Check‑in date — Check‑out date” button (7005) opens the calendar.  
Action: Click [7005]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Try clicking the “April 2025” month–year heading inside the calendar; many Booking calendars let you open a month selector this way, which could let us jump straight back to February 2024.  
Action: Click [15817]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Scrolling upward inside the calendar may move the displayed months backward (toward February 2024).  
Action: Scroll [16004]; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to set travelers to 2 adults + 2 children. Expand the “Number of travelers and rooms” button.  
Action: Click [7464]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to locate the traveler controls (plus/minus buttons) that likely sit above; scrolling up should reveal them.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The plus/minus controls for Adults and Children likely sit above but remain out of view. Scrolling the window further up should reveal them so we can adjust children to 2.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Plus/minus buttons for Adults and Children are likely just above these StaticText labels but still out of view; need to scroll window further up to bring them into view.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The “Done” button (16230) will close the travelers panel so we can proceed to pick the correct dates and later reopen it to add 2 children.  
Action: Click [16230]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Action: Click [7005]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to bring the “Previous month” arrow into view to navigate back to February 2024. Scrolling the Calendar panel upward should reveal it.  
Action: Scroll [16590]; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Earlier months may be above in this scrollable calendar panel; we need to keep scrolling the calendar upward until February 2024 appears.  
Action: Scroll [16590]; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar’s top (with the “Previous month” arrow) is probably above the current viewport; scrolling the window upward should reveal it so we can navigate back to February 2024.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The “Previous month” arrow is probably still further above within the calendar panel; keep scrolling the Calendar panel upward to reveal earlier months.  
Action: Scroll [16590]; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar overlay may extend above this viewport; scrolling the main window upward could reveal the hidden “Previous month” control we need to navigate back toward February 2024.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Keep scrolling the calendar panel upward to reach earlier months until February 2024 appears.  
Action: Scroll [16590]; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Continue scrolling the calendar tabpanel upward; the navigation row with “Previous month” should appear once we reach the very top of this scrollable area.  
Action: Scroll [16590]; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Persist in scrolling upward inside the calendar (tabpanel 16590) until earlier months appear; we’re still on April/May 2025, so more upward scrolling is required.  
Action: Scroll [16590]; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Open a property page, where the date‑picker may behave normally; click the first hotel’s “Show prices” button.  
Action: Click [9795]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Finish selecting a date range (checking-out on May 31 2025). After the range is chosen, the calendar should re‑enable the month‑navigation arrows, including the “Previous month” arrow we need to move back toward February 2024.  
Action: Click [16509]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to reopen the calendar to set the correct February 14–21 2024 dates.  
Action: Click [7005]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar now shows both navigation arrows. We must move backward month‑by‑month toward February 2024.  
Action: Click [17341]

Observation: please analyze the accessibility tree and give the Thought and Action.
